revision.text:
In linguistics, '''variable rules analysis''' is a set of [[statistical analysis]] methods commonly used in [[sociolinguistics]] and [[historical linguistics]] to describe patterns of [[Variation (linguistics)|variation]] between alternative forms in language use. It is also sometimes known as '''Varbrul analysis''', after the name of a software package dedicated to carrying out the relevant statistical computations (''Varbrul'', from "'''var'''ia'''b'''le '''rul'''e"). The method goes back to a theoretical approach developed by the sociolinguist [[William Labov]] in the late 1960s and early 1970s, and its mathematical implementation was developed by Henrietta Cedergren and [[David Sankoff]] in 1974.<ref>Cedergren, H.; and Sankoff, D. (1974). Variable rules: Performance as a statistical reflection of competence. ''Language'', ''50'', 333-355.</ref>
A variable rules analysis is designed to provide a quantitative model of a situation where speakers alternate between different forms that have the same meaning and stand in [[free variation]], but in such a way that the probability of choice of either the one or the other form is conditioned by a variety of context factors or social characteristics. Such a situation, where variation is not entirely random but rule-governed, is also known as "structured variation". A variable rules analysis computes a [[multivariate analysis|multivariate]] statistical model, on the basis of observed token counts, such that each determining factor is assigned a numerical factor weight that describes how it influences the probabilities of choice of either form. This is done by means of [[stepwise regression|stepwise]] [[logistic regression]], using a [[maximum likelihood]] algorithm.
Although the necessary computations required for a variable rules analysis can be carried out with the help of mainstream general-purpose statistics software packages such as [[SPSS]], it is more often done by means of a specialised software dedicated to the needs of linguists, called ''Varbrul''. It was originally written by David Sankoff and currently exists in [[freeware]] implementations for [[Mac OS]] and [[Microsoft Windows]], under the title of ''Goldvarb X''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://individual.utoronto.ca/tagliamonte/goldvarb.html|title=Sali A. Tagliamonte: Goldvarb|website=individual.utoronto.ca}}</ref> There are also versions implemented in the statistical language [[R (programming language)|R]] and therefore available on most platforms. These include ''R-Varb'' and ''Rbrul''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danielezrajohnson.com/rbrul.html|title=Rbrul|website=www.danielezrajohnson.com}}</ref>
Variable rules approaches are commonly employed for the analysis of data in sociolinguistic research, especially in studies that aim to investigate how reflexes of linguistic change through time appear in the shape of structured variation patterns within a speech community.<ref>Tagliamonte, S. (2006). ''Analysing Sociolinguistic Variation.'' Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.</ref>
==See also== *[[Diaphoneme]]

revision.text:
{{short description|1718-1906 series of illustrated antiquarian papers on ancient buildings, sites, and artefacts}} {{Italic title}} [[File:Roman mosaics from Vetusta monumenta (Vol.1, 1826).jpg|thumb|Roman [[mosaic]]s from [[Wellow, Somerset]] near [[Bath, England]], double page spread in volume 1, in an 1826 reprint]] '''''Vetusta Monumenta''''' is the title of a published series of illustrated [[antiquary|antiquarian]] papers on ancient buildings, sites, and artefacts, mostly those of Britain, published at irregular intervals between 1718 and 1906 by the [[Society of Antiquaries of London]]. The [[Folio (printing)|folio]] sized papers, usually written by members of the society, were first published individually, and then later in collected volumes.<ref name="Harris">{{cite web|url=http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/makinghistory/recording-and-illustrating,444,AR.html|title=: Antiquaries in Britain, 1707–2007 - Recording and illustrating|last=Harris|first=Greg|work=Making History|publisher=Royal Academy of Arts|accessdate=24 November 2010}}</ref>
==Publication== The full title is ''Vetusta monumenta quae ad Rerum Britanicarum memoriam conservandam Societas Antiquariorum Londini sumptu suo edenda curavit'', but the volumes are normally simply cited as ''Vetusta Monumenta''. There were various reprints of both individual papers and collected volumes, and the plates were often published separately from the text. According to the HOLLIS database at [[Harvard]]: "The seven volumes are dated 1747, 1789, 1796, 1815, 1835, 1883 and 1906 (for the fourth part of vol.7). The plates for vol. 1 were published between 1718 and 1747; plates for vol. 2 were published between 1748 and 1789; plates for vol. 3 were published between 1790 and 1796; plates for vol. 4 were published between 1799 and 1815; plates for vol. 5 were published between 1816 and 1835; plates for vol. 6 were published between 1821 and 1885; plates for the four parts of vol. 7 were published between 1893 and 1906."<ref>[http://eresearch.lib.harvard.edu/V/T9H1EJI2QMR5XA1E97JX3K8YYF9GRUU5N3ISA1YINE3AHKKV3T-77390?func=quick-1 HOLLIS database at Harvard] (dynamic link - enter title)</ref>
The series began the same year that the society formalized its existence with the first minuted meeting on January 1, 1718, at the Mitre Tavern, [[Fleet Street]]; the society's main journal ''[[Archaeologia_(London)#Publications|Archaeologia]]'' did not begin publication until 1770. Members of the society received a free copy as each part was published.<ref>Harris, [http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/makinghistory/founding-the-society-of-antiquaries,449,AR.html ''Founding the Society of Antiquaries''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306034954/http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/makinghistory/founding-the-society-of-antiquaries,449,AR.html |date=March 6, 2012 }} and ''Recording and illustrating'', as above.</ref>
==Contents== The emphasis was on the large and detailed illustrations, initially high quality [[engravings]], which conveyed information on the subject matter in an accessible and economical way.<ref name="Nurse">{{cite web|title=The Embarkation of Henry VIII at Dover 1520|last=Nurse |first=Bernard (Librarian, RSA)|work=alecto historical editions|accessdate=23 November 2010|location=United Kingdom}}</ref> Each issue was usually developed from papers and research of the society, giving a text description accompanied by illustrated details it had commissioned. The assemblage of maps, site plans, and other detail was a novelty that found popular appeal.
The views in the series contained images of people and other means of conveying scale, providing the perspective of the interested visitor. These accompanied text descriptions for the sites, but provided additional information with high levels of detail and multiple or idealised viewpoints to simulate a well informed tour. Many of the plates show the setting, inset with exploded views, cross sections and other architectural details, or objects found at the site. Other figures were interspersed with the text, or taking up several full pages. Critics have compared this approach with contemporaneous works that included the subject as an attractively sketched scene, illustrations were not yet recognised as a valuable source of information. The book used the multiple and separate details to synthesise encyclopaedic surveys that typified the approach of the natural historians and antiquaries, what [[Barbara Maria Stafford]] has described as "cross-referencing material bits of distant reality".<ref name="Arnold1999">{{cite book|last=Arnold|first=Dana|title=The metropolis and its image: constructing identities for London, c. 1750-1950|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ke4X4HjHTi8C&pg=PA14|accessdate=23 November 2010|year=1999|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-0-631-21667-4|pages=14–16|chapter=Atheticizing the Ancestral City}}</ref>
An 1803 article on the [[Rosetta Stone]] was amongst the earliest published research.<ref>1803: "Has tabulas inscriptionem ... ad formam et modulum exemplaris inter spolia ex bello Aegyptiaco nuper reportati et in Museo Britannico asservati suo sumptu incidendas curavit Soc. Antiquar. Londin. A.D. MDCCCIII" in Vetusta Monumenta vol. 4 plates 5–7</ref> The first detailed account of the medieval French [[Royal Gold Cup]] in the [[British Museum]] was published in one of the last papers, of 1904, by Sir [[Charles Hercules Read]].<ref>Read, Sir Charles Hercules. ''The Royal Gold Cup of the Kings of France and England, now preserved in the British Museum''. ''Vetusta Monumenta'' Volume 7, part 3, 1904</ref>
==Contributors== The following is an incomplete list of noted contributors, and their articles:<!-- eg. the DNB, 1900 --> * [[Thomas Astle]] * [[Thomas Amyot]], a description of [[Tewkesbury Abbey]] * [[William Wilkins (architect)|William Wilkins]], 'Observations on the Porta Honoris of Caius College, Cambridge' * [[George Gwilt the Younger]], architect * [[Browne Willis]], 'A Table of the Gold Coins of the Kings of England.' (1733)<ref name="Chalmers1817">{{cite book|last=Chalmers|first=Alexander|title=The General biographical dictionary: containing an historical and critical account of the lives and writings of the most eminent persons in every nation: particularly the British and Irish; from the earliest accounts to the present time|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qW1kAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA144|accessdate=24 November 2010|volume=32|year=1817|publisher=Printed for J. Nichols|pages=143–4|chapter=Willis, Browne}}</ref> *[[Thomas Walford]] (iii. pt. 39)<ref name=DNB00>{{cite DNB|wstitle =Walford, Thomas|first =Edward Irving |last = Carlyle |authorlink =Edward Irving Carlyle|volume=59}}</ref>
Notices on illustrations mention the following engravers: * [[George Vertue]], engraver to the society. Produced a drawing of the [[Holbein Gate]] in 1724, his 1727 engraving appears in volume 1, 1747.<ref>'[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=67926 The Holbein Gate and the Tiltyard Gallery]', Survey of London: volume 14: St Margaret, Westminster, part III: Whitehall II (1931), pp. 10-22. Date accessed: 24 November 2010.</ref> Other works include the portrait of Richard II at Westminster, the shrine of Edward the Confessor, and a view of [[Waltham Cross]]; nearly all the copperplate to 1756 was engraved by Vertue.<ref name=DNB1>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Vertue, George|last=O'Donoghue|first=Freeman Marius|authorlink=Freeman Marius O'Donoghue}}</ref> * [[James Basire]] (1730–1802), one of Vertue's successors, who produced large and exquisite design on copperplate. His descendants of the same name, the son James Basire (1769–1822) and grandson (1796–1869), were also appointed engraver of the Society. His work for the volumes—after his appointment in the 1760s—is described as amongst his best,<ref>{{cite DNB|title=Basire, James, et al.}} citing Redgrave, ''Dict''.</ref> however, * [[William Blake]], Basire's apprentice is thought to be partly, if not largely, responsible for many of the designs.<ref name="Wright2003">{{cite book|last=Wright|first=Thomas|title=Life of William Blake|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CdFWtiMjVzgC&pg=PA4|accessdate=24 November 2010|date=2003-02-01|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-2852-1|page=4}}</ref> * [[Charles Alfred Stothard]], coloured facsimile of the [[Bayeux Tapestry]] in 1818<ref>'The Bayeux Tapestry' in Encyclopædia Britannica, 1911.<!-- unverified, needs checking --></ref> * [[Jacob Schnebbelie]] (d. 1826), draughtsman to the society. Executed many of the architectural views of the second and third volumes.<ref name="Hone1832">{{cite book|last=Hone|first=William|title=The year book of daily recreation and information|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=brIPAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA25|accessdate=23 November 2010|year=1832|publisher=[[Thomas Tegg]]|pages=219–20}}</ref> * [[Samuel Hieronymous Grimm]]
==References== {{Reflist|}}
==Further reading== *Grazia Lolla, Maria. ''Ceci n'est pas un monument: Vetusta Monumenta and antiquarian aesthetics'', in ''Producing the Past: Aspects of Antiquarian Culture and Practice, 1700-1850'', eds Martin Myrone and Lucy Peltz, 1999, Ashgate

page.title: Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana | image = Molina dictionary.jpg | author = [[Alonso de Molina]] | country = [[Mexico]] | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Nahuatl language|Nahuatl]] | genre = [[Dictionary]] | publisher = [[Juan Pablos]] | release_date = 1555 }}
'''''Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana''''' is a bilingual dictionary of [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Nahuatl]] by [[Alonso de Molina]], first published in 1555 originally entitled ''Aquí comiença un vocabulario en la lengua castellana y mexicana'', edited by Juan Pablos. It was the first dictionary to be published in the [[New World]]. However the most relevant and most famous edition was the one made in 1571, edited by Antonio de Spinosa, which then came to be named ''Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana''. This new edition included the Nahuatl-to-Spanish section that the original didn't.
The [[Franciscans|Franciscan missionaries]] promoted the writing of literature works to evangelize the Indians in their own language, Nahuatl being language one of the most important considering that it was spoken throughout [[New Spain]]. After the [[Council of Trent]], the hierarchy of the Catholic Church recommended to preach in indigenous languages.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hernández|first1=Esther|title=Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana de fray Alonso de Molina, edición facsímil y estudio preliminar|publisher=Ediciones de Cultura Hispánica|location=Madrid, España|accessdate=13 December 2015}}</ref> During the rule of viceroy [[Martín Enríquez de Almanza]], Molina published Spanish-to-Nahuatl and Nahuatl-to-Spanish vocabularies to help the formation of priests that were to accomplish the evangelizing assignments.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Centro de Estudios de Historia de México Carso|title=0 años Centro de Estudios de Historia de México Carso. Fundación Carlos Slim.|date=2015|publisher=Fundación Carlos Slim|location=México|page=145|edition=first|accessdate=13 December 2015}}</ref>
Molina's ''Vocabulario'' is considered the most important dictionary of the [[Classical Nahuatl language]] and has continued to be reprinted into the 20th century.<ref>{{cite book |author=Andrews, J. Richard |year=2005 |title=Introduction to Classical Nahuatl |others=revised edition |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press |page=658}}</ref> It is typically referred to simply as ''Molina''.
==First printed vocabulary of an indigenous language== [[File:13.- 50003 0004 - Alonso de Molina - Vocabulario en lengua mexicana y castellana c 1565.tif|thumb|Aquí comiença un vocabulario en la lengua castellana y mexicana]] It is believed that Nahuatl was the first of the [[indigenous languages of the Americas]] to be linguistically studied, since the first preserved grammar of an American language is ''Arte de la lengua mexicana'' (1547) by [[Andrés de Olmos]]; moreover, shortly after in 1555, the first vocabulary of an indigenous language was published: Molina's vocabulary.
This first edition of the dictionary only contained the Spanish-to-Nahuatl section, based on which Molina made the 1571 edition adding the Nahuatl-to-Spanish section.
==Formal characteristics== The 1571 ''Vocabulary'' de 1571 is divided in two sections, very much like modern bilingual dictionaries, individually foliated: the Spanish-to-Nahuatl section consists of 118 sheets and the Nahuatl-to-Spanish one, of 162 sheets. There are 4 columns on each sheet and each one of them contains approximately 35 entries, thus containing 16500 Spanish-to-Nahuatl entries and 22600 Nahuatl-to-Spanish entries.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hernández|first1=Esther|title=Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana de fray Alonso de Molina|date=1996|publisher=Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas|location=Madrid, España|accessdate=13 December 2015}}</ref>
The first section is headed by the printing licenses and a letter to New Spain's viceroy, D. Martínez Enríquez.
Both sections are preceded by a foreword in which he justifies the work and where a series of notifications about the peculiarities of the Mexican language appeared.
At the end of the first section there is an attachment, that already appeared in the 1555 edition, where the Franciscan gives grammatical instructions of the numbers in Nahuatl, with equivalences in Spanish.
==Editions== There are 7 known editions: *1555. ''Aquí comiença un vocabulario en la lengua castellana y mexicana''. *1571. *1880, by Julios Platzman, Leipzig. *1910, by Rufino González, Puebla Talleres el Escritorio, only Spanish-to-Nahuatl. *1944, facsimile edition by Colección de Incunables americanos, siglo XVI, v. IV, Madrid, Cultura Hispánica. *1966, abbreviated and modernized edition. *1970, 1977 reprint. Mexico, Porrúa, preliminar study by [[Miguel León-Portilla]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://alfama.sim.ucm.es/dioscorides/consulta_libro.asp?ref=B23658927&idioma=0 Digital reproduction of ''Vocabulario en lengua castellana y mexicana''], in the website of the [[Complutense University of Madrid]]. {{es icon}} * [https://archive.org/details/vocabulariodela00platgoog Full online facsimile of the book] at the [[Internet Archive]] {{es icon}}

{{Infobox ancient site | name = Warwasi | native_name = | alternate_name = | image = | alt = Warwasi | caption = | image_size = 240 | map_type =Iran | map_alt = Warwasi | map_caption = location in Iran | map_size = 240 | relief = yes | coordinates = {{coord|34|27|34|N|47|6|18|E|display=inline,title}} <!-- EDITORIAL NOTE: not exact coords--> | location = north of [[Kermanshah]] | region = [[Iran]] | type = | part_of = | length = | width = | area = | height = | depth = | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = from [[Middle Paleolithic]] to late [[Epipaleolithic]] | cultures = | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = | ownership = | management = | public_access = | website = | notes = }} [[File:Kermanshah Pal Museum-Neanderthal.jpg|thumb|270px|A reconstruction of a Neanderthal male at [[Zagros Paleolithic Museum]]]] '''Warwasi''' is a [[Paleolithic]] rockshelter site located at north of [[Kermanshah]] in western [[Iran]]. It was [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavated]] by [[Bruce Howe]] under direction of late [[Robert John Braidwood|Robert Braidwood]] in the 1960s. This site contains a rich archaeological sequence from [[Middle Paleolithic]] to late [[Epipaleolithic]].

{{Primary sources|date=May 2009}} <!-- Please take a moment to read through this article's talk page before making major additions to the article. -->{{Infobox Website |name = You're the Man now Dog! | logo = [[File:YTMND Logo Transparent.png]] | url = [http://www.ytmnd.com/ YTMND.com] | screenshot = | commercial = Yes | type = Specialized website community/[[List of Internet phenomena|Internet fad]] and [[meme]] website | registration = Optional | owner = [[Max Goldberg]]/YTMND, Inc. | author = [[Max Goldberg]] | launch date = 2000 | alexa = {{Decrease}} 85,895 ({{as of|2018|11|10|alt=November 2018}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/ytmnd.com |title= Ytmnd.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2018-11-10 }}</ref> }}'''YTMND''', an initialism for "'''You're the Man Now, Dog'''", is an [[virtual community|online community]] centered on the creation of hosted [[Internet meme|memetic]] web pages (known within the community as ''fads'', ''YTMNDs'' or ''sites'') featuring a [[wikt:juxtaposition|juxtaposition]] of an image (still or short animation) centered or tiled along with optional large zooming text and a looping sound file. Images and sound files used in YTMNDs are usually either created or edited by users. YTMND is generally a humor website, owing its tone and culture to the original YTMND and its early imitators. Other YTMNDs, however, are artistic or political.
== History == YTMND originated in 2000 from Max Goldberg's original website, "[http://www.yourethemannowdog.com/ yourethemannowdog.com]", which he registered along with "[http://www.dustindiamond.com/ dustindiamond.com]" after seeing a [[trailer (film)|trailer]] for the movie ''[[Finding Forrester]]'' in which [[Sean Connery]] says the line "You're the man now, dog!". Originally, the website featured the text "YOURE THE MAN NOW DOG.COM" drawn out in [[3D computer graphics|3D]] [[ASCII art|ASCII text]] with a sound loop from the ''Finding Forrester'' trailer of [[Sean Connery]] reciting the phrase "You're the man now, dog!".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.yourethemannowdog.com/ | title=Yourethemannowdog.com from October 7, 2001 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20011007184416/http://www.yourethemannowdog.com/ | archivedate=2001-10-07 | accessdate=2007-04-09}}</ref> The advent of zoomed text currently on the website was seen in the following months, where the website also featured a photograph of [[Sean Connery]].<!-- this is awkward --> Goldberg's new creation inspired others to make similar sites with other movie and television quotations (or any other sound clip they wished to use).<ref name="wired">{{cite news | url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.11/meganiche.html?pg=2&topic=meganiche | publisher=[[Wired News]] | title=Wired 14.11: Tiny Slice, Big Market | accessdate=2007-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.yourethemannowdog.com/ | title=Yourethemannowdog.com from December 3, 2001 | publisher=Internet Archive | accessdate=2006-07-24 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20011203020131/http://www.yourethemannowdog.com/ |archivedate = 2001-12-03}}</ref> At first, Goldberg maintained a list and [[mirror website|mirror]] of these sites,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.yourethemannowdog.com/contrib/ | title=Yourethemannowdog.com/contrib from March 30, 2005 | accessdate=2006-08-12 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050306071851/http://www.yourethemannowdog.com/contrib/ | archivedate=2005-03-06}}</ref> but the list soon became exceptionally long.<ref name="ytmndabout">{{cite web|url=http://www.ytmnd.com/info/about|title=About YTMND| publisher=YTMND|accessdate=2006-06-12}}</ref> [[File:Ytmnd-screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|262px|A 2011 screenshot of yourethemannowdog.com.]] In 2004, Goldberg wrote a [[news release|press release]] after winning a lawsuit filed by [[Dustin Diamond]] for the "fan page" at the aforementioned dustindiamond.com. He mentioned yourethemannowdog.com, as well as a new website, YTMND, that would be ready by April 10. The website opened that day after a rushed coding and design process. The site caught on in popularity and became an [[list of Internet phenomena|Internet phenomenon]] when major [[blog|weblogs]] and [[Internet forum]]s began linking to the ''[[The Picard Song|Picard Song]]'' YTMND.<ref name="ytmndabout" />
=== Height of popularity ===
In November 2005, YTMND changed its layout and added new features, including a comment management system and new lists for the main page.<ref name="nov2005">{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=3 | title=Welcome to the new face of ytmn(d-sfw)! | date=2005-11-25 | publisher=YTMND | accessdate=2006-06-18 }}</ref> A feature debuted soon after allowing users to donate money on behalf of a YTMND chosen by the user in exchange for its increased exposure through the main site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=7|title=Fund raising|publisher=YTMND|accessdate=2006-06-12}}</ref>
On September 24, 2006, YTMND changed to a new layout and design.<ref name="sep2006">{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=50 | title=Create like a god, command like a king, work like a slave | date=2006-09-24 | publisher=YTMND | accessdate=2006-09-24}}</ref> The re-design added new features, such as the YTMND digest.<ref name="ytmndigest">{{cite web|url=http://www.ytmnd.com/browse/digest|title=YTMND – browse sites|publisher=YTMND|accessdate=2006-09-24}}</ref> <!--More features? Anyone?-->
=== Decline ===
On August 29, 2016, Max Goldberg that YTMND would likely soon be shutting down, citing ill health and the site's inability to fund its own hosting fees in ad revenue. Goldberg stated "Besides being a time capsule I don’t really see a reason for it to continue to exist... It seems like the internet has moved on...And I’ve moved on too. I don’t have much interest in the site beyond it being good memories."<ref>https://gizmodo.com/who-killed-ytmnd-1785765611</ref> Despite this, the site remains open as of September 2018. On May 12, 2018, the site stopped accepting new user signups as a result of [[Google]] shutting down version 1 of its [[ReCAPTCHA]] [[Anti-spam techniques|anti-spam mechanism]].
== Conflicts ==
=== eBaum's World === In January 2006, [[eBaum's World]] hosted and [[digital watermarking|watermarked]] a [[Lindsay Lohan]] [[montage (filming)|montage]] created by YTMND user SpliceVW without crediting either SpliceVW or YTMND. In response to their actions, users from YTMND joined users from other Internet communities and launched an attack on the forums on eBaum's World, using spam posting and [[denial-of-service attack]]s to repeatedly crash them.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}}
Goldberg denounced the ongoing attacks, stating that they had "really crossed the line" and were a "vulgar display of power".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=13 | title=And the complaints come marching in | date=2006-01-08 | publisher=YTMND | accessdate=2006-06-12}}</ref> He later stated that any YTMND member whose site promoted attacks would have his or her account deleted<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=15 | title=Your account will be deleted if... | publisher=YTMND | date=2006-01-09 | accessdate=2006-06-12}}</ref> and that the conflict had placed both himself and his hosting company in a negative light.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=16 | title=To clarify my statement | date=2006-01-09 | publisher=YTMND | accessdate=2006-06-12}}</ref>
On January 10, eBaum's World alleged the attacks were a form of [[cyberterrorism]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://ebaumsworld.com/response-01-10-06.html | title=Regarding the recent attacks on eBaum's World | date=2006-01-10 | publisher=eBaum's World | accessdate=2006-06-12 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060601071237/http://www.ebaumsworld.com/response-01-10-06.html | archivedate=2006-06-01 | df= }}</ref> and on January 11, Neil Bauman, the executive vice president of eBaum's World, publicly stated that arrests were being made in relation to the attacks.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060113071643/http://www.wcmf.com/Images/Docs/Links/1-11.mp3 Statement from Neil Bauman]</ref> Eventually, Goldberg and Bauman came to an agreement: Bauman removed the montage from his website, and Goldberg removed references to "eBaum" from his.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=17 | title=Cease and Desist from Neil Bauman | date=2006-01-10 | publisher=YTMND | accessdate=2006-06-12}}</ref> Though the conflict was resolved, both sites experienced DDoS attacks on the morning of January 12, 2006.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=20 | title=The never ending saga | date=2006-01-12 | publisher=YTMND | accessdate=2006-06-12}}</ref>
=== Church of Scientology === On June 10, 2006, a [[cease and desist]] form was sent to Goldberg by lawyers of the [[Church of Scientology]], claiming that several YTMND pages with Scientology-related content had infringed on Scientology copyrights.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ytmnd.com/info/l_ron.html |title=Church of Scientology sends a cease and desist |publisher=YTMND |accessdate=2006-06-13 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060623073505/http://www.ytmnd.com/info/l_ron.html |archivedate=2006-06-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In response, Goldberg replied to the lawyer that the cease and desist form was "completely groundless" and he would not be deleting any Scientology-related sites.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=39 | title=What you know about dat | date=2006-06-13 | publisher=YTMND | accessdate=2006-06-13}}</ref> Days later, a [[Scientology]] page section appeared on the front page along with a disclaimer on the bottom stating the following: ''"This website is in no way affiliated, sponsored or owned by the Church of Scientology, [[L. Ron Hubbard]], [[Sea Org|SeaOrg]], [[Dianetics]], volcanoes or aliens of any sort. We are, however, sponsored by Citizens for the Release of [[Xenu]], a not-for-sanity organization."'' According to Goldberg, there have not been any recent updates regarding the potential lawsuit.<ref name="Scientomogy">{{cite web|url=http://www.scientomogy.com/ytmnd.php|deadurl=yes|title="backup" copy [courtesy of the "archive dot org" site called the "Wayback machine"] of Scientomogy.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070218200403/http://www.scientomogy.com:80/ytmnd.php |archivedate=February 18, 2007|work=scientomogy.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=41 | title=Green onions | publisher=YTMND | date=2006-06-23 | accessdate=2006-06-23}}</ref>
=== "Moon Man" and YouTube === [[File:Mac Tonight.JPG|thumb|YTMND courted controversy with the character "Moon Man", based on McDonald's mascot [[Mac Tonight]]]] The YTMND character "Moon Man", a white supremacist rapper character based on source videos of the [[McDonald's]] advertising campaign [[Mac Tonight]], garnered controversy shortly after its first remix in 2007. [[AT&T]]'s [[text to speech]] program provided Moon Man's voice and was soon edited to block any racially derogatory epithets or swear words in an attempt to cull the number of remixes. McDonald's began removing existing Mac Tonight sculptures and animatronics from some of its restaurants in response to the widespread remixes, and [[YouTube]] began automatically striking down many Moon Man-related videos from 2007 to the present. Several videos were also [[DMCA]]-claimed and taken down by McDonald's from 2007–2008. Multiple [[change.org]] petitions were filed demanding YouTube cease removing the videos, the most recent of which from May 2015 having reaching over 1200 signatures. YouTube has since stopped taking Moon Man videos down unless they have been flagged by users.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Burke|first1=Timothy|title=Rape, Murder, Violent Racism: The Weirdest McDonald's Ad Campaign Ever|url=http://theconcourse.deadspin.com/rape-murder-violent-racism-the-weirdest-mcdonalds-ad-1673970057|website=The Concourse|publisher=The Concourse|accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref>
=== Sega === On January 11, 2007, Goldberg revealed that [[Sega Europe]] had sent a [[cease and desist]] letter concerning the "Sonic Says..." fad, which features a clip from the [[Adventures of Sonic the Hedgehog|Sonic animated series]]. The letter alleged that consumers "may be confused into believing that [the offending pages are] in someway [sic] linked to or associated with" the company.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=56 | title=Misirlou | publisher=YTMND | date=2007-01-11 | accessdate=2007-01-11 }}</ref> In its letter, Sega stated that it would take legal action after seven days if ownership of all "that's no good" web domains were not handed over. After almost two weeks of silence following the original 7-day limit, Goldberg declared the issue had "blown over."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=57 | title=Deception | publisher=YTMND | date=2007-02-01}}</ref>
=== Scholastic === On July 17, 2007, Goldberg received a string of letters and phone calls from lawyers representing [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]] threatening legal action if sites revealing spoilers for ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'' were not removed, in response to several YTMNDs with scanned pages that Goldberg posted on the front page. As more sites were created with spoilers, additional letters were sent. Goldberg responded to Scholastic by declining to take down Harry Potter-related sites.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ytmnd.com/news/?news_id=74 |title=Magic |author=Max |date=July 19, 2007 |work= |publisher=YTMND.com |accessdate=8 September 2010}}</ref>
=== Pez === In May 2009, the [[Pez]] corporation sent a cease-and-desist letter regarding two YTMNDs depicting fake Pez dispensers with [[Adolf Hitler]] and [[Charles Manson]]'s heads on the containers, which they found insulting, and demanded that YTMND refrain from allowing any Pez-related items to be displayed on the site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.ytmnd.com/Pez|title=Pez|work=ytmnd.com}}</ref> Goldberg responded by starting a fad contest involving the candy company, with the prize being a possible [[lawsuit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ytmnd.com/contests/?contest_id=6|title=ytmnd – you're the man now dog!|work=ytmnd.com}}</ref>

{{Infobox museum |name = Istanbul Archaeology Museums |native_name = İstanbul Arkeoloji Müzeleri |native_name_lang = |image = İstanbul Arkeoloji Müzeleri (collage) - Arkeoloji Müzesi (üstte), Eski Şark Eserleri Müzesi (solda), Çinili Köşk Müzesi (sağda).jpg |imagesize = 260 |caption = |alt = |map_type = Turkey Istanbul |map_caption = Location of Istanbul Archaeology Museums |map_alt = |coordinates = {{coord|41.010872|28.981659|display=inline}} |established = 13 June 1891 |collection = 1+ million objects |location = Osman Hamdi Bey Yokuşu Sokak, Gülhane, [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] |type = Archaeology museum |visitors = 382.148 (2011) <ref name="ministryofculture">{{cite web|url=http://www.kulturvarliklari.gov.tr/TR,43336/muze-istatistikleri.html6|title=Ministry of Culture and Tourism - Museum Statistics |publisher=kultur.gov.tr|date=January 1, 2012|accessdate=December 5, 2012}}</ref> |director = Zeynep Kızıltan |website = [http://www.istanbularkeoloji.gov.tr/ Istanbul Archaeology Museum page] }}
The '''Istanbul Archaeology Museums''' ({{lang-tr|{{italics correction|İstanbul Arkeoloji Müzeleri}}}}) is a group of three archeological museums located in the [[Eminönü]] district of [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]], near [[Gülhane Park]] and [[Topkapı Palace]].
The Istanbul Archaeology Museums consists of three museums: #'''Archaeological Museum''' (in the main building) #'''Museum of the Ancient Orient''' #'''Museum of Islamic Art''' (in the [[Tiled Kiosk]]).
It houses over one million objects that represent almost all of the eras and civilizations in world history.
==Background== In the 19th century, efforts were in place to modernize the [[Ottoman Empire]], as many of the leading statesmen were exposed to Westernizing ideas through education and travel. The proposal to have an imperial museum came about because of the familiarity of several key players in the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] political scene with the [[Louvre]] in [[Paris]].<ref name="hurriyetdailynews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=istanbul-archaeology-museum-turning-120-2011-06-26|title=ARTS-CULTURE - Istanbul Archaeology Museum turning 120 |work=[[Hürriyet Daily News]]|date=June 26, 2011|accessdate=February 20, 2012}}</ref> The Ottoman sultan [[Abdülaziz]] (r. 1861–1876) was impressed by the archaeological museums in [[Paris]] (30 June – 10 July 1867),<ref name=AbdulazizVoyage/> [[London]] (12–23 July 1867)<ref name=AbdulazizVoyage/> and [[Vienna]] (28–30 July 1867)<ref name=AbdulazizVoyage/> which he visited in the summer of 1867,<ref name="AbdulazizVoyage">{{Cite news|url=http://blog.milliyet.com.tr/sultan-abdulaziz---avrupa-seyahati/Blog/?BlogNo=367847|title=Sultan Abdülaziz - Avrupa Seyahati/Tarih/milliyet blog|work=blog.milliyet.com.tr|access-date=2018-02-28}}</ref> and ordered a similar archaeological museum to be established in Istanbul. The decision to establish an Imperial Museum under the Education Ministry came in 1869 with the appointment of a new director, but the idea of a museum was dropped with his resignation and because of budget restraints.
As education minister in 1872, [[Ahmet Vefik Pasha]] set up a museum directorship for the second time and hired the [[Germany|German]] historian, archaeologist, epigraphist and painter, Dr. Phillip Anton Dethier. He proved to be so successful at collecting materials that the idea of a purpose-built museum gained traction.
When Dethier died in 1881, [[Painting|painter]] and [[archaeologist]] [[Osman Hamdi Bey]] was appointed to the position that same year.
==History== [[Image:Osman Hamdi Bey bust March 2008.JPG|thumb|left|Bust and memorial plaque to [[Osman Hamdi Bey]] in the foyer of the main building]] The site of the museums belonged to the [[Topkapı Palace]] outer gardens. The museum was founded by decree as the Imperial Museum ({{lang-ota|Müze-i Hümayun}} or {{lang-tr|İmparatorluk Müzesi}}) in 1891. The first [[curator]] and founder of the museum was [[Osman Hamdi Bey]]. Since an imperial decree protecting cultural goods in the Ottoman Empire was enforced, many governors from the provinces would send in found artefacts to the capital city. In that way the museum was able to amass a great collection. Upon its 100th anniversary in 1991, the museum received the [[European Council]] Museum Award, particularly for the renovations made to the lower floor halls in the main building and the new displays in the other buildings.
The construction of the main building was started by [[Osman Hamdi Bey]] in 1881, attaining its present neo-Greek form in 1908. The architect was [[Alexander Vallaury]] (who also designed the [[Pera Palace Hotel]] in Istanbul). The facade of the building was inspired by the [[Alexander Sarcophagus]] and Sarcophagus of the Mourning Women, both housed inside the Museum. It is one of the prominent structures built in the [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]] style in Istanbul.
The '''Museum of the Ancient Orient''' was commissioned by Osman Hamdi Bey in 1883 as a fine arts school. Then it was reorganised as a museum, which opened in 1935. It was closed to visitors in 1963, and reopened in 1974 after restoration works on the interior.
The '''[[Tiled Kiosk]]''' was commissioned by Sultan [[Mehmed II]] in 1472. It is one of the oldest structures in Istanbul featuring [[Ottoman architecture|Ottoman]] civil architecture, and was a part of the Topkapı Palace outer gardens. It was used as the Imperial Museum between 1875 and 1891 before the collection moved to the newly constructed main building. It was opened to public in 1953 as a museum of Turkish and Islamic art, and was later incorporated into the Istanbul Archaeology Museum.
==Hours of operation, admittance fee== The museum is open to the public from 09:00 to 19:00, with ticket sales halting an hour before closing time; tickets are 20 TL. Closed on Mondays. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.istanbularkeoloji.gov.tr/visiting_hours_and_admission|title=İstanbul Arkeoloji Müzeleri - Visiting Hours And Admission|publisher=Istanbularkeoloji.gov.tr|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref>
==Collection== The ornate Alexander Sarcophagus, once believed to be prepared for [[Alexander the Great]], is among the most famous pieces of ancient art in the museum.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/travel/guides/europe/turkey/istanbul/attraction-detail.html?vid=1154654614207|title=Istanbul Archaeology Museum|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 18, 2009|accessdate=February 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120524104810/http://travel.nytimes.com/travel/guides/europe/turkey/istanbul/attraction-detail.html?vid=1154654614207|archivedate=May 24, 2012|df=}}</ref>
The museum has a large collection of [[Turkish people|Turkish]], [[Hellenistic civilization|Hellenistic]] and [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] artifacts, many gathered from the vast former territories of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. The most prominent artifacts exhibited in the museum include: *The [[Alexander Sarcophagus]], found in the necropolis of [[Sidon]] *[[Sarcophagus]] of the Crying Women (Sarcophagus of the Mourning Women), also found in Sidon (in fact, the sarcophagus of Strato I, king of Sidon) *The [[Tabnit sarcophagus]] and the Satrap sarcophagus. *The [[Lycian sarcophagus of Sidon]] *Glazed tile images from the [[Ishtar Gate]] of [[Babylon]] *Statues from ancient antiquity until the end of the [[Roman Era]], from [[Aphrodisias]], [[Ephesus]] and [[Miletus]] *Statue of an [[Ephebos]] *Parts of statues from the [[Pergamon Altar|Temple of Zeus]] found at [[Pergamum|Bergama]] *A marble lion from the [[Mausoleum of Mausolus]], one of the few pieces remaining in Turkey *Snake's head from the [[Serpentine Column]] erected in the [[Hippodrome of Constantinople]] *Mother-Goddess [[Cybele]] and votive stelai *Busts of [[Alexander the Great]] and [[Zeus]] *Fragments from the temple of [[Athena]] at [[Assos]] *The [[Troy]] exhibit *800,000 [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] coins, seals, decorations and medals *Two of the three tablets of the [[Egyptian–Hittite peace treaty]] (1258 [[BCE]]), signed between [[Ramesses II]] of Egypt and [[Hattusili III]] of the Hittite Empire. It is the oldest known peace treaty in the world, and a giant poster of these tablets containing the treaty is on the wall of the [[United Nations Headquarters]] in [[New York City]]. *The [[Saba'a Stele]] of the [[Assyria]]n king [[Adad-nirari III]] *Tablet archive containing some 75,000 documents with [[cuneiform]] inscriptions (including the [[Istanbul 2461|Istanbul #2461]] tablet, containing the oldest known love poem) *Artifacts from the early civilizations of [[Anatolia]], [[Mesopotamia]], [[Arabia]] and [[Egypt]] *[[Siloam inscription]], which made headlines in July 2007 when Israel asked for its return<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2007-07-13-tablet_N.htm|title=Jerusalem seeks return of ancient tablet|work=[[USA Today]]|date=July 13, 2007|accessdate=June 24, 2010}}</ref> *[[Gezer calendar]] *[[Balawat gates]] (one gate) *[[Samaria ostraca]]
